para.paratext: An expert witness may state an opinion about what is or is not due care or proper conduct if he is familiar with a particular business or operation and has knowledge beyond that of a reasonably prudent juror.[1]
The witness may state his opinion as to the standard of care required, but should not add a conclusion that the conduct of a particular individual was or was not negligent.[2]
It is the function of the witness to give the jury a standard of care to be used to determine whether or not a reasonable degree of care and skill was exercised under the facts in issue.

Under the so-called “locality rule,” a testifying expert must base his opinion regarding the standard of care required of some medical personnel on his knowledge of the area in question. In Wade v. John D. Archbold Memorial Hosp.,[3] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that while the locality rule had been abandoned in regard to the standard of care applicable to physicians, it was still applicable to hospitals. On appeal the Georgia Supreme Court limited the scope of the locality rule by holding it inapplicable to a hospital physical therapist.[4]

It was within the discretion of the court to qualify a structural engineer as an expert on the standard of care expected of a contractor. Coursey Bldg. Associates v. Baker, 165 Ga. App. 521, 301 S.E.2d 688 (1983).
